description.narrative:
FN:s livsmedels- och jordbruksorgan (FAO) har presenterat ett projektförslag för en treårig insats (2020–2022). Det övergripande målet för insatsen är en övergång till en ekonomiskt och miljömässigt hållbar landsbygd för samhällen och områden som har påverkats av konflikt och naturkatastrofer. Det slutgiltiga målet är en minskning av multidimensionell fattigdom. Den huvudsakliga målgruppen är offer som tvångsförflyttats från sin mark av väpnade grupper, och som nu har fått domslut om återbördande som del av landåterlämningsprocessen. Projektet kommer dock att ha ett territoriellt fokus och jobba även med andra grupper bosatta i samma områden. Denna insats är en fortsättning av FAO:s tidigare insatser för resiliens mot naturkatastrofer och väpnad konflikt, landåterlämning till offer för den väpnade konflikten samt produktiva aktiviteter för hållbar utveckling.
Insatsens totala budget är 85,4 miljoner kronor varav organisationens eget bidrag är 10,4 miljoner kronor (1 084 000 USD). Sverige är den enda givaren till denna insats av projekttyp och det svenska bidraget kommer att uppgå till 75 miljoner kronor.

The Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) has presented a project proposal for a three-year contribution (2020-2022). The general objective of this contribution is to achieve a transition to an economically and environmentally sustainable rural context for communities and territories affected by conflict and natural disasters, with the ultimate goal of reducing multidimensional poverty. The main target population are victims of land grabbing that were forcibly displaced by illegal armed groups and now have favourable restitution rulings as part of the land restitution process. However, the project will have a territorial approach, working with other communities that share the same territories. This contribution is continuation of FAO’s previous contributions concerning resilience to natural disasters and armed conflict, land restitution to victims of the armed conflict and productive processes for sustainable development.
The intervention’s total budget is 85,4 million SEK, out of which the organisation’s own funding is approximately 10,4 million SEK (1.084.000 USD). Sweden is the single donor to this project-type intervention and the Swedish contribution will be 75 million SEK.

The contribution’s objective is formulated as an impact, an outcome and four outputs. The impact is formulated as follows: Contribute to overcoming women’s, men’s, girls’ and boys’ multidimensional poverty in the prioritized areas, which have been affected by the armed conflict. The outcome is formulated as follows: The policy for victims’ integral reparations in targeted municipalities has been strengthened through a resilient, sustainable and innovative model of economic reactivation, scalable to other areas of the country; The four outputs are the following. 1. Prioritised communities in areas affected by armed conflict have optimised their productive, social and commercial activities based on resilient and risk-conscious means of subsistence. 2.Communities and institutions in the prioritised areas have implemented practices for better, environmentally sustainable ecosystem services related to their productive, economic and social surroundings. 3.Prioritised communities in conflict-affected territories have incorporated technological and financial innovation systems to optimise their productive processes. 4. Institutional and community networks are constituted as platforms for impacts, management and coordination on integral reparations to victims in the prioritised territories.

description.narrative:
This reporting period was dramatically affected by the Covid 19 global pandemic that delayed many regional activities. However, as it was the first year of project implementation, the project focused on consolidating the new team, presenting the project to the public institutions involved in the implementation process and to develop a regional characterization to collect the baseline and to identify the context of conflict and land dispossession. In addition, 14 regional analyses of environmentally sustainable ecosystem services were developed.
This characterization process is very important to have the right direction in contributing to overcoming women's, men's, girls and boys multidimensional poverty, as well as for the participatory approach with the 2.122 participants as well as the 1.449 families that are part of collective reparation processes in Bolívar and Córdoba. Up to May 2021, 36 peasant farmer associations have been identified, 8 of which are headed by women. All associations were evaluated through a rural entrepreneurship scheme (that includes 10 variables) and the associations received scores ranging from 4 to 66 which will be an important parameter to compare with by the end of the project. This diagnostic process has also resulted in 8 territorial initiatives on resilience and sustainability that are integral regional strategies with specific action plans for each region and is how FAOs activities are articulated with public policies such as the PDET or the Integral Project for Agricultural and Rural Development (PIDAR).
As regards the third output, FAO gathered information on unpaid domestic work carried out by the women participants of the project, as a way of incorporating innovative practices and the use of information and communication technologies (ICTs) that favor an adequate and balanced time management system and participants proposed solutions, which viability will be verified by local teams. As regards the financial inclusion, FAO is introducing the concept of mutual contingency funds based on periodic savings by associates/members. This strategy combines financial education, savings, risk management and entrepreneurship abilities. In addition, an alliance between FAO and Mibanco has been established through a Memorandum of Understanding, signed on June the 23rd 2021. The objective is that Mibanco, that has a guarantee with Sida for a loan portfolio of ten million US dollars, could support FAO in financial education, savings and subsequently, guaranteed loans for the projects participants.
As regards the fourth output, the aim is to continue implementing the strategy of Local Networks for Productive Integration (RLIP is its Spanish acronym), that has been consolidated over the last two years as a way of improving the socio economic and environmental sustainability of local businesses. During the last year specific social and gender activities were prioritized in all the regions as well as a communication strategy to visibilize communitarian participation and results. To coordinate better with public institutions, quarterly technical meetings were held at a national level to discuss progress, results and plans.
